data.text: Sun Rashes and Sun Burn when Bike Touring

Anyone has experience with sun rash / sun burn while traveling? I was on the road in Poland between Legnica and WrocÅ‚aw when I accidentally passed by LubiÄ…Å¼ Abbey. This is one of Europe's biggest Cistercian monasteries. And it was so so beautiful!! But after that, due to the warm weather and lack of sun protection, I got sunburn which then evolved into sun rash. I eventually put our neck warmer around my legs so that the sun couldn't make it worse... Do you have experience with sun rash while traveling or bikepacking, and how do you deal with it?

If you're interested, watch my journey to WrocÅ‚aw here: https://youtu.be/MGgpUs0GFno
Bikepacking to WrocÅ‚aw & sun burn I DAY 3
youtube.com

data.text: Zinc-paste. Only thing that works in high mountains anyway. Avoid over eyes, wear a cap
data.author: Staffan Jonson

data.text: oh good one.. any zinc paste is good? Thank you!
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: surely they differ. Price usually says.
data.author: Staffan Jonson

data.text: okay thank you!
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: I managed to badly burn the back of my legs. A wet towel at night helped and I used lots of aloe vera gel. It was the one place I didn't put suncream on as I thought my wheel and and panniers would protect them.
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: Stay away from Odra river!
data.author: Robert Mac

data.text: why is that?:)
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: Long sleeves. Loose clothes. ðŸ§´

data.text: oh yeah didn't think about loose clothes.. that is because of the heat?

data.text: sun poncho
data.author: Brian Eustachian

data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: Years ago an old chap mentioned, that the areas of his body that never saw the sun were in so much better condition than those that did. Now I'm in my 60s I can't emphasise enough how true this is. Wear sunscreen. Always wear sunscreen. We always wear long sleeved shirts, preferably those with a collar, particularly after hubby had pre-cancerous cells removed from his neck.
data.author: Shirley Acreman

data.text: thank you for sharing that!! I will definitely be careful after reading your message.. more sunscreen and more long sleeve clothes! Thanks
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: My wife died of skin cancer when she was 32 (in 1986), so I keep covered up.
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: I'm sorry to hear that! Good advice to cover up, thank you ðŸ™‚ nice picture btw! What kind of bicycle is that?
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text:
It's a recumbent bicycle . This particular one is an AZUB Six with under seat steering: https://azub.eu/recumbent-bikes-and-trikes/recumbents/six/

data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: Antihistamine to prevent sun rash
data.author: Sarah Smith

data.text: Cover your skin to prevent sunburn. Antihistamine is after the damage has been done
data.author: Emma Adams

data.text: definitely. I put sun tan lotion and take antihistamine to prevent sun rash
data.author: Sarah Smith

data.text:
thank you! Yeah, I actually took an antihistamine pill, I mentioned the name in my video but can't remember the name of the pill anymore ðŸ˜… https://youtu.be/MGgpUs0GFno Thank you for sharing that though, I don't know if it helped me though... Does it help you immediately or more on the long term?
Bikepacking to WrocÅ‚aw & sun burn I DAY 3
youtube.com
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: yeah, as an Australian , knowing all too well the risk of skin cancer, I would not recommend antihistamines because it seems that would lull people into a false sense of security. The best medicine is to avoid sunburn altogether.
data.author: Emma Adams

data.text: Here in Australia you cannot get sunscreen less than factor 50. It works. Cream up before you need it and reapply during the day. Sports formulations are good because they do not wash off with sweat.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: ow, didn't know that there is nothing under 50! What is the highest there then? And thanks for the tips :)
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: wear a light buff / bandana / neckerchief around my neck and also one over my ears. along with my cap under my helmet. Stop me getting brunt neck, burnt ears, burnt nose.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: yeah the neckerchief/buff is what helped my legs to cover up the sun burn, but by then it was already too late... Thanks for the tip for better face protection!!
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: aloe Vera gel.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: As an Australian, I am slightly bemused
data.author: Emma Adams

data.text: haha what do you mean?
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: Long sleeves, long pants, wide brimmed hat.ðŸ˜†
data.author: Herman Chauw

data.text: taking notes! :)
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: After getting burnt it can still be helpful to apply lotion, some people swear by aloe vera, there is a brand of lotion called solarcaine which has a numbing agent if the burn is painful.
data.author: Ren Dodge

data.text: oh thank you so much didn't know this lotion. So for you that one works the best?
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: The solarcaine, or anything with lidocaine is best for pain, any moisturizing lotion will help healing a little bit, but it still takes time to heal.
data.author: Ren Dodge

data.text: For me, I just use regular lotion, idk the brand, Jergens maybe. I have used other lidocaine for blisters and stuff, but not sunburn. It will work for pain though.
data.author: Ren Dodge

data.text: Sudocream
data.author: Roman Pertzian

data.text: oh thank you, I didn't know that one
data.author: Clara Francken

data.text: Cover up while in the sun and treat burns with Aloe
data.author: Jake Klamerus
